msContents.summary: For a discussion of the manuscript see Christopher Baswell, Virgil in Medieval England (Cambridge, 1995), ch. 2 (pp. 41—83), `Pedagogical exegesis of Virgil in medieval England: Oxford, All Souls College 82.' The manu¬script is described ibid. 290-I and pl. 82 reproduces fol. 36`, reduced.' The manuscript is also described by B. Munk Olsen, L'Etude des auteurs classiques latins . , ii (Paris, 1985), 752-3 and recorded by R. Cormier, `A Preliminary Checklist of Early Medieval Glossed "Aeneid" Manuscripts', Studi medievali, 32 (1991), 971-9, at 976.

msItem.incipit: Fol.1r.. Publii .V. Maronis Bucolicon incipit. Titire tu patule recubans sub tegmine fagi . . .
msItem.explicit: [fol. 10r/40]. . . Ite domum sature uenit hesperus ite capelle. hic finis ostenditur Bucolici carminis.
msItem.author: Virgil
msItem.title: Eclogues

note.p: Ecloga. At the top right hand corner of fol. ir, in the main hand, apparently to rectify its omission, is the Ps.-Ovid Argumentum, 'Qualis bucolicis 〈quantus tenure domanda〉 . lege munere nostro' (four verses), ed. D. R. Shackleton Bailey, Anthologia Latina, i (Stuttgart, 1982), II, and Anthologia Latina, ed. A. Riese (Leipzig, 1894), 16; Walther, Initia, 15117; D. Schaller and E. Könsgen, Initia carminum Latinorum saeculo undecimo antiquorum (Göttingen, 1977), 12948. In Eclogues, Geoigica, and Aeneis the scribe queried some readings, suggested alternatives, and made some neat corrections in the text, which, as Professor Baswell points out in a private communication, show contact with a different but good text in the general tradition of Vatican, MS Pal. Lat. 1631.

msItem.incipit: Fol. 10r/40.Prefacio. Quid faciat letas segetes quo sidera \uel e/ seruet . . .
Quid faciat letas segetes quo sidere terram . . .
msItem.explicit: [fol. 35r]. . . Tytire te patule cecini sub tegmine fagi.
msItem.author: Virgil
msItem.title: Georgics

note.p:
Georgica, preceded by the Ps.-Ovid Argumentum (four verses, ed. Bailey, Anthologia Latina, 12, Anthologia Latina, ed. Riese, i/ 1. 16). In the righthand margin of fol. 29r, in the main hand, apparently to rectify an omission, is the Ps.-Ovid Argumentum to the fourth Georgic, 'Protinus aerii mellis redolentia regna . . . Indicat humentisque fauos celestia dona', Bailey, 13;
Anthologia Latina, ed. Riese, i. 17, ii. 4; Schaller and Koönsgen, 12695. There are a very few glosses. Fol. 35v is blank; fol. 36 is a triangular stub; see Structure below.

msItem.rubric: Virgilii Maronis Eneidos primus liber incipit.
msItem.incipit: Arma virumque cano troie qui primus ab oris...
msItem.explicit: [Fol. 150v]Vitaque cum gemitu fugit indignata sub umbra. Virgilii Maronis Aeneidos Liber duodecimus explicit
msItem.author: Virgil
msItem.title: Aeneid

note.p: Aeneis, preceded by the Ps.-Ovid Argumentum to bk. 1 (Bailey, Anthologia Latina, 2). The Ps.-Ovid Argumenta to bks. 2-12 precede each book, written in the text, and line 15 of the Argumentum to bk. 7 is repeated at the end of that book (fol. 100v), marked in the margin 'Versus Ouidii Nasonis.' At the top right-hand corner of fol. 37r, in the main hand, is the Ps.-Virgil Praefatio Aeneidos, beg. 'Ille ego qui quondam gracili modulatus auena', Schaller and Koönsgen, 7713, Walther, Initia, 8699. Bks. 1-3 are quite heavily glossed and bk. 7 has a number of glosses but there are few elsewhere. The glosses are in three layers, of ss. xii, xiii2 and xiv2. The earliest layer, Baswell's Comm. I, IA, probably contemporary with the manuscript and possibly by the scribe of the text, is largely Servian in content but also draws on Macrobius's Saturnalia; the second layer, Baswell's Comm. II, a series of brief lexical and grammatical glosses, mostly interlinear, is in bk. 1 only (s. xiii2); the third layer, Baswell's Comm. III (s. xiv2), is selective, probably composed by its scribe, and includes material from Servius and Anselm of Laon. On the glosses see Baswell, Virgil, 48-80.

msContents.msItem:
(i) Fol. 150v. Carmen octauiani cesaris. de uirgilio. Ergone suppremis potuit uox improba uerbis... [fol. 151r]... Laudetur. iugeat. placet. relegatur. ametur.
Thirty-six verses, Anthologia Latina, ed. Riese, i/2. 145, no. 672; Schaller and Koönsgen, 4517; Walther, Initia, 5508.
(ii)Fol. 151r. Virgilii versus ad imperatorem. Nocte pluit tota redeunt spectacula mane I Diuisim imperium cum ioue cesar habes. I Hos ego uersiculos feci. tulit alter honorem. I Sic uos non uobis mellificatis apes. I Sic uos non uobis uellera fertis oues. I Sic uos non uobis fertis aratur boues. Ps.-Virgil
Ps.-Virgil, six verses. Verses 1-2 ed. Bailey, Anthologia Latina, 189; cf. Schaller and Koönsgen, 10279; Walther, Initia, 1188; verses 3-4 ed. Bailey, 190; Schaller and Koönsgen, 7221; Walther, Initia, 8447. Verses 5-6 not found.
(iii) Fol. 151r. Ovidius in Virgilium. Virgilius magno quantum concessit homero... Liuoris titulum proposuisse tibj. Ps.-Ovid
Ten verses. Ps.-Ovid Argumenta metrica to the Aeneid. Ed. Bailey, Anthologia Latina, 1; Anthologia Latina, ed. Riese, i. 7; Schaller and Koönsgen, 17116; Walther, Initia, 20188.
(iv) Fol. 151`. Virgilius de semetipso. Meonium quis-quis Romanus nescit homerum . . . Hec grais constant singula trina mihi. Virgil (attrib.), six verses. Anthologia Latina, ed. Riese, ii (1906), 15o; Schaller and Konsgen, 9167; Walther, Initia, 10963.
(v) Fol. IV. Exprobacio in vetulam. Quatuor ut memini fuerant tibi delia dentes . . . Furis habes nomen. ueniat tibi nominis omen. Virgil (attrib.), twenty-six verses. Schaller and Konsgen, 13142. Walther, Initia, 15333.
(vi) Fol. 151". Primus habet libicam ueniant ut troes in urbem . . . Ultimus imponit bello. turni nece finem. Twelve verses. Anthologia Latina, ed. Riese, wo, no. 634; Schaller and Konsgen, 12542. Walther, Initia, 14661.
(vii) Fol. 151". (a) Sus iuuenis. serpens casum uenere sub unum I sus iacet extinctus sibilat hic moriens. (b) Intereant et eant ad tartara non redituri I Qui teneros pueros proconiuge sunt habituri. (a) Five verses. Bailey, Anthologia Latina, 112, no. 149; Anthologia Latina, ed. Riese, i/1. 148; Schaller and Konsgen, 15908; Walther, Initia, 18931. (b) Virgil (attrib.), two lines. Walther, Initia, 9489, Proverbia, 12660. Written in the left margin beside item vi, also in the same hand.

support.p: Fore- and endleaves: fol. ir, numbers; fol. iv, blank; fol. iir, title and pen-trial; fol. iiv, blank; fol. iiir, blank; fol. iiiv, ex libris; fol. ivr, blank; fol. ivv, obliterated identification letters; fols. ir—ivv, blank.

recordHist.source: Andrew G. Watson, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Medieval Manuscripts of All Souls College Oxford (Oxford, 1997)

availability.p: For enquiries relating to this manuscript please contact library@all-souls.ox.ac.uk.
